docs.lead_paragraph: State employee unions, continuing their fight with the Rowland administration over medical coverage, have charged that changes in employee health plans are discriminatory. The State Employee Bargaining Agent Coalition has filed a complaint with the State Commission on Civil Rights and Opportunities contending that the administration is illegally trying to prevent some disabled people from being allowed to go to doctors outside their plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: In four of New Jersey's 13 Congressional districts, challengers are mounting campaigns strong enough to give the incumbents some sleepless nights, while the other nine incumbents seem to be walking toward victory on Tuesday. Nationally, Democrats may hold out a slim hope that they can swing the balance of power back to their side of the aisle, but in New Jersey absolutely everything would have to go right for the Democrats to take control of the delegation, which now has seven Republicans and six Democrats, all of whom are running for re-election.

headline.main: Who's Running for Congress or, in Some Cases, Walking

docs.lead_paragraph: The other day, while Washington was going up in flames, the two candidates for what is probably the most important office at stake in the 1998 elections, the governorship of California, held a debate in Sacramento. Gray Davis, the Democrat, is a veteran liberal politician whose fate it is to be known for the goodness of fit between his first name and his mien. Dan Lungren, the Republican, is a hearty, easy-talking guy whose reputation over the years has been as something close to a movement conservative. The debate, their third in a series of five, had a disorienting quality. The candidates had obviously decided in advance that they were going to ''go negative,'' so they tried to be mean, sarcastic and vicious toward each other. They huffed and interrupted. Davis made sure to work in a reference to his military service. (Lungren didn't serve.) Lungren made sure to work in a reference to his three children. (Davis is married but childless.) The debate's tonal culmination was Lungren's use of his closing statement to advance a cheerfully out-of-left-field theory about the undetected assonance between the police unions' support of Gray Davis and the notorious incident in which Latrell Sprewell, the basketball player, throttled his coach.

headline.main: The New American Consensus; Government of, by and For the Comfortable

docs.abstract: Nicholas Lemann article on relatively new but powerful working consensus between Republicans and Democrats on most major issues; cites race for center by candidates of both parties around nation; sees new consensus forged through heavy use of public-opinion polls; says view spawned by Great Depression that big government is needed to protect people from worst vagaries of market economy has been replaced; says most Americans now believe government should serve middle class, but that middle class has no obligation to commit time or money to larger national projects; sampling of American family portraits (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Americans go to the polls on Tuesday, don't expect seismic shifts -- or even loud noises. Things are comfy right now, and even with background worries about the economy, the Zeitgeist seems to be: We like where we are. Pass the microbrew. As surveys indicate, middle America is more upscale than it used to be -- liberal socially, conservative economically. In the following data stream, moderation reigns, strikingly so, perhaps explaining why Bill Clinton and his poll-tested policies have stayed popular during this Presidential annus horribilis. * The typical American family -- a white married couple with 1.89 children -- lives in a house it owns and has a pet, most often a mixed-breed dog or a nothing-special domestic short-hair cat. * Favorite sport utility vehicle: the Ford Explorer. * Most couples consider good sex vital to a marriage's success, but have sex about once a week -- for an average of 39 minutes. * Given $1,000 to invest, 73 percent of respondents in a recent survey would still bet on stocks. * The Top 10 things recently ranked by Americans as in: jeans, the Internet, female athletes, gourmet coffee, kids, alternative medicine, ethnic food, angels and volunteerism. * Growth of red-wine sales in the U.S. from 1991 to 1997: 151 percent. * Growth of Internet usage since 1995: 167 percent. * Almost everybody -- 99 percent -- thinks the Government wastes a portion of their tax dollars. * Most doubt that they will be able to afford health care in the next 10 years. * Most believe contraceptives should be covered by health insurance, even if premiums rise slightly. * A majority of Americans now dress casually for work everyday. * Seven of 10 want stricter gun-control laws and oppose repealing the assault-weapons ban. * The number of Americans who have tried cappuccino, latte or another espresso-based product grew by 34 percent from 1997 to 1998. * Seventy-six percent of Americans oppose a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion. * Sixty percent of all U.S. households carry credit-card debt. Average balance: $7,000. * Three of four families still eat together regularly, but the dinner hour is speedy -- 30 minutes or less. * A majority of Americans, of all races, support mending not ending affirmative action. * Most Americans (80 percent) support President Clinton's plan to lower the average class size in public schools. * More than 90 percent feel safe in their neighborhoods. * The average American family generates more than 2,500 pounds of garbage each year; 76 percent recycle cans, bottles or paper. * Nearly two-thirds don't find the air nearly clean enough -- and want Uncle Sam to do something about it. * Two-thirds want to restrict human cloning. * Favorite pizza topping: pepperoni. * Eight of 10 adults agree that the Social Security system faces serious problems requiring Congress' immediate attention. * Two-thirds favor allowing homosexuals to serve in the military. * Sixty-three percent think a sexual encounter between a powerful man and a less-powerful woman at the office does not automatically constitute sexual harassment. * Favorite actress: Meg Ryan and Helen Hunt (tie). * Favorite airline for long-distance flights among frequent fliers: T.W.A. * Ninety percent own dental floss, but most neglect to use it every day. * Americans, by a 2-to-1 margin, oppose bilingual education; most people would agree to carry a national identity card if that deterred illegal immigration. * Most people agree with the statement, ''The United States Constitution is important to me,'' but more than half don't know that there are 100 senators. More American teen-agers can name the Three Stooges than the three branches of the Federal Government. * An overwhelming majority believe in God (and most believe in the devil, too), belong to a church and pray silently at least once a day. * Favorite style of eggs: scrambled. * Most voters want TV and radio networks to provide political candidates with free air time. * A majority believe the government should ban smoking in public places like stores and restaurants. * Favorite sneakers: Nike.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alfonse M. D'Amato ABORTION -- Opposes legalized abortion, and voted for a constitutional amendment holding that life begins at conception. Has voted at times to allow exceptions to save a woman's life or in cases of rape or incest, but has also voted against such exceptions. Would restrict a type of late-term procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion. CRIME -- Supports the death penalty and has voted for stricter mandatory sentencing in Federal crimes, particularly those in which guns are used. Has opposed gun control laws and voted against the 1994 crime bill and the assault weapons ban. Typically favors tougher punishments over spending on prevention programs. ECONOMY AND TAXES -- Consistently opposes tax increases, but has voted for budget bills that include some increases. Has proposed legislation to give middle-class homeowners a $500 property tax credit. EDUCATION -- Supports merit pay raises for teachers and has proposed testing to gauge teachers' competence. Supports giving teachers and principals greater authority to remove violent and disruptive students. HEALTH CARE -- Has proposed legislation that would require insurance companies to pay for reconstructive surgery for mastectomy patients and allow doctors to determine the length of a hospital stay after a mastectomy. Has voted to cut the rate of increase in Federal Medicare spending. CIVIL RIGHTS -- Opposes affirmative action and racial quotas in hiring. Voted for an antidiscrimination bill for gay people and supported a policy allowing gay people to serve openly in the military. ENVIRONMENT -- Has supported some major environmental bills, including reauthorization of the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts, but has also frequently supported legislation making it more difficult to enforce environmental regulations. Charles E. Schumer ABORTION -- Supports abortion rights and has voted against restrictions, including parental notification for teen-agers and mandatory 24-hour waiting periods. Also supports Medicaid financing for abortions for poor women. Opposes most restrictions on late-term abortions. CRIME -- Supports the death penalty. Supports strict gun control laws and was the primary author of the 1994 crime bill and assault weapons ban. Favors preventive measures like drug treatment and youth programs. Has opposed some bills requiring stricter mandatory sentencing. Has voted for increased authority for use of wiretaps by investigators. ECONOMY AND TAXES -- Has voted in favor of increased taxes and Government spending. Has proposed a plan to boost New York's economy by cutting electricity rates, making pensions portable, offering tax credits to encourage home ownership in poor neighborhoods, reducing air fares upstate, cutting payroll taxes and using funds from any Government settlement with the tobacco industry to reduce property taxes. EDUCATION -- Favors making all college tuition tax deductible. Opposes giving parents vouchers for private-school tuition. Has voted against cuts in Government spending on student loan programs and school lunches. HEALTH CARE -- Supports stricter regulation of health maintenance organizations, including giving patients the right to sue over malpractice or the denial of necessary care. Has voted against proposals to cut the rate of Government spending on Medicare. CIVIL RIGHTS -- Supports affirmative action, equal rights protections for gay people and benefits for domestic partners. ENVIRONMENT -- Voted to strengthen the Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, Endangered Species Act and the Marine Mammal Protection Act.
